section.title: Definition
section.para: Deployment elements - test-install, test-update and publish - provide settings to complete the following tasks:

listitem.para: Publish a repository to a file system location on the build machine.
Assemble files and information related to installing and updating client machines using that repository.
Optionally, execute user-provided scripts to perform testing, installation, updates, notification and other deployment-related tasks.

TEXT value to be used as the root user password for the client machine. This value is provided as a module macro %{password}.
This element is optional. If not provided, a random password is automatically generated. The generated password is stored in the repository data file. See for information on the repository data file.

Deploy also generates an encrypted version of the password and makes it available as the module macro %{crypt-password}. The encrypted password is recommended for use in the kickstart element. See the element below for an example. The encrypted password is also stored in the repository data file.

BOOLEAN value controlling whether Deploy will attempt to execute scripts directly on the client machine identified by the %{fqdn} module macro using SSH. Scripts are defined using the element. See for more information on BOOLEAN values.

This value serves as a default for the module. If the value is TRUE, Deploy will use SSH for an individual script based on the value of the script's ssh attribute. See the script element for additional information on the attribute.

If the value is FALSE, Deploy will not use SSH for any script. If a script has been defined that requires SSH, either by default or via the ssh attribute of the script element, Deploy will fail with an error message.

Setting the value to FALSE allows users to provide custom support for remote script execution, on one or multiple client machines, using any method desired. This custom support must be embedded within user-provided scripts.

Deploy supports public key authentication for SSH connections. If the value of the ssh element is TRUE, Deploy will check to see if SSH has been configured for the root user on the build machine. Specifically, it does this by testing for the existence of a file named /root/.ssh/id_rsa.pub. If this file does not exist, Deploy will attempt to configure SSH for the build machine by executing the following command:
/usr/bin/ssh-keygen -t rsa -f /root/.ssh/id_rsa -N ""
If SSH keys have been previously created for the root user, and those keys require the use of a passphrase, the passphrase may be specified using the element.

listitem.para: The ssh element is optional. The default value is TRUE.
TEXT value specifying the SSH passphrase, if any, for the root user on the build machine.
This element is optional. The default value is an empty string, "".
TEXT value specifying install boot environment variables, also known as kernel boot arguments, for use during client machine installation. Ignored if the element is set to package.
Boot options are typically used in combination with a kickstart file to automate client machine installations. See the element below for more information.

The boot-options element's text value should be a space-separated list of kernel arguments. For more information on available boot options, see the chapter on Boot Options in the Red Hat Enterprise Linux Installation Guide
Provided as a module macro, %{boot-options}, for use within deployment element content, primarily install-type scripts. See the element below for more information.
Also used by Deploy during the creation of installation images including boot.iso and images created by the ISO module. See for more information on the ISO module.
Boot-options is an optional element. The default value is "lang=en_US keymap=us".
Specifies the TEXT of a kickstart file. Ignored if the element is set to package.

A kickstart file allows automating Anaconda system installation by providing answers to install-time questions such as selection of language, network configuration, keyboard, file system configuration, mouse, timezone and root password.

Deploy makes the kickstart available as a file named ks.cfg included in the root folder of the repository, e.g. http://server.company.com/repos/system/samba-server-5-i386/ks.cfg. It also includes the kickstart in all ISO images including boot.iso.
The kickstart file is used by Anaconda, the CentOS system installer, for obtaining options, such as language, timezone, network and machine configuration, during automated installation.
For information on creating kickstart files, see the chapter on Kickstart Installations in the Red Hat Enterprise Linux Installation Guide, available from the Red Hat website.
Kickstart is an optional element. If not provided, users will be prompted for information at the time of client machine installation.

note.para: It is not necessary to specify a '%packages' section in the kickstart file. Deploy automatically configures the installer to install all packages in the repository. If a '%packages' section is provided, it is ignored.

Where possible, avoid using the 'firewall' and '%post' kickstart options, as they are applied only during client installation. Instead, use config-rpms to apply client configuration. This ensures uniform results whether the client is installed from scratch, or merely updated. See the httpd-config.xml template for an example of firewall configuration using a config-rpm.

Tests current trigger values against prior trigger values. Must return a non-zero exit status if a trigger has changed. See also the element.

Deploy makes a number of macros available to assist with test-trigger script operation. These are listed in , under the label Trigger Macros. The example below shows how they can be used in a test-triggers script.
Example - This example shows a file named test-triggers.xml which is included in the templates folder at /usr/share/deploy/templates/deploy. See for more information on templates.

The template first reads a file (identified by the %{trigger-file} macro) of saved trigger values. Using a list of triggers identified by the %{triggers} macro, it then attempts to compare current trigger values to saved trigger values. Deploy calculates a number of current trigger values and makes them available via the %{release_rpm}, %{config_rpms}, %{kickstart}, %{treeinfo}, %{install_scripts} and %{post_install_scripts} macros. If any of the current triggers differs from the corresponding saved trigger, the script returns an exit status of '1'.

Deletes or decommissions one or more client machines in preparation for system installation. Must return a non-zero exit status if machine deletion fails. Commonly used with the %{fqdn} module macro.

Example - In this example, a bash script is used to destroy and undefine a virtual machine specified using the %{fqdn} module macro. The command set -e is used at the beginning of the script to indicate that if any command in the script fails, the script should return a non-zero exit status. Typically bash scripts return the exit status of the last command executed in the script.
Installs one or more client machines. Must return a non-zero exit status if installation fails. Commonly used with the %{fqdn} and %{url} module macros.
Example - This example uses two elements kickstart and install-script.
The kickstart element provides settings for the client machine. A kickstart is also required for automated system installation.

The install-script element provides a bash script which completes the actual machine installation. In this case, the script executes the virt-install command to create a new virtual machine. The script uses the %{fqdn} module macro to specify a name for the virtual machine, as well as the filename for the machine's image. It uses the %{url} macro to specify the location for the installation files, as well as for the kickstart file.
The set -e command has not been used in this script as it was in the example. In this case it is unnecessary because the script contains only a single command, virt-install.
Performs post-install tasks such as install verification. Must return a non-zero exit status if post-install tasks fail.

The script can perform any desired actions to verify system installation. One recommended action is to scan the /root/install.log file for "scriptlet failed" errors. Scriptlet failed errors identify issues in which RPM packages, quite possibly one of the config-rpms (defined using a element), failed to install as expected. See the examples section below for a script that scans for and reports "scriptlet failed" errors. See the Deploy User Manual for information on troubleshooting "scriptlet failed" errors related to the config-rpm.

Example - In this example the post-install-script element provides a bash script which uses the grep to scan for scriptlet failed errors in the install.log. If errors are found, the script returns an exit status of '1', indicating that verification failed.
Saves trigger values for future use by test-triggers-type scripts. Must return a non-zero exit status if trigger save unsuccessful.
Example - This example shows the save-triggers.xml file which is included in the templates folder at /usr/share/deploy/templates/deploy. See for more information on templates.
The script in this template saves trigger values to a file specified by the %{trigger-file} macro. The %{trigger-file} macro, along with other macros used by this script are defined in .

Performs tasks that should occur each time the deployment module runs, e.g. when deployment scripts change or when RPM packages are updated in the deployment repository. Post tasks might include performing client updates, restarting clients if the kernel package has been updated, or shutting down a client if its purpose has been accomplished during the course of module execution (e.g. building or testing RPMs). Must return a non-zero exit status if post tasks fail.

For the publish event, this script is useful for copying published repositories to remote download servers. It can also be used to integrate repositories with enterprise systems management systems, for example to sync repository content with software channels in Red Hat Network or Spacewalk. In scenarios such as these, it is necessary to set the @ssh attribute to a false value.

For the test-install and test-update events, the post-script is useful for activities such as completing testing that should run after either install or update, or for powering down test machines between runs.
Updates an installed client, typically by executing the yum sync or yum update commands, followed by performing update verification as desired.

The update-script may also be used for post processing after client updates. For example, the update-script may be used to test the running system kernel and restart the machine if a new kernel version has been installed, as is shown in the example update-script below. Note that while post processing actions such as these could be performed in either the update-script or the post-script, the former is preferable since the latter is executed after both installation and updates.

Example - In the following example, a bash script is provided that updates the client using the yum sync command. Thereafter, the script tests for a new kernel, and restarts the client if one is found. The set -e is used to halt processing and return a non-zero exit status if an error occurs at any point within the script.
Examples - In this example, the post-script is a simple bash script with a single command to shut down the client machine.
This attribute is required.
BOOLEAN value that determines whether Deploy should attempt to execute the script via SSH. Default values are shown in the table below.

If the ssh attribute is TRUE, Deploy attempts to copy the script to the client machine identified by the %{fqdn} macro and execute it from the /var/lib/deploy/ folder with root privileges. The file will be given the same name as the attribute.
If the ssh attribute is FALSE, Deploy relies on the script to perform all steps to connect, authenticate, and execute on one or more client machines.
BOOLEAN value indicating whether the Standard Output from the script should be displayed as output from Deploy.
This attribute is optional. The default value is FALSE

TEXT value providing a space or comma-separated list of scripts, identified by their values, that should execute following preceding this script.
TEXT content of a script used for determining whether the deployment event should run during the current Deploy session. Deploy executes the script on the local machine as the root user.
Provides a single run-time macro:
%{input-dir}: The path to a folder where the input-script should copy files.
Deploy tests for changes in files in the %{input-dir} folder based on filename and timestamp. If any files have changed, it causes the deployment event to run.
The input-script element is optional. One or more elements are allowed.

In most cases this element is not required as Deploy automatically runs the event only when necessary. In some cases, however, it is desirable to cause the event to run based on external factors, such as changes to a file used by one of the scripts described in the previous element.

Example - in the example below, the text of a script is provided. The script tests if the current version of a source code repository matches the version saved to a file in the %{input-dir} folder. If not, it writes the new version to the file. Deploy checks for changes to files in the %{input-dir} and, if so, causes the deployment event to run.

informalexample.programlisting:
<input-script> #!/bin/sh # track the latest source code repository revision so that tests run each # time the repository changes
set -e file=%{input-dir}/hgtip hgtip_curr=`hg identify https://example.com/path/to/hg/source/code/repo` hgtip_last=`[ -f $file ] && cat $file || echo ''` if [[ $hgtip_curr != $hgtip_last ]]; then echo $hgtip_curr > $file fi </input-script>
